title: FTC Asks Kroger for More Information on Albertsons Deal; Regulators scrutinize $20 billion deal that would merge two of the biggest names in the U.S. grocery industry
text:
The request extends the 30-day waiting period, established under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act of 1976, that federal antitrust regulators have to challenge a merger. The window will now remain open until 30 days after both Kroger and Albertsons have complied with the requests, unless the FTC elects to close it sooner.

Kroger said it still expects the deal, which the companies said values Albertsons at $24.6 billion when including the assumption of debt, to close in early 2024.

The grocers announced the blockbuster deal in October, saying that a merger would give them greater scale and better leverage in negotiations with vendors. The combination would also give the companies a better footing to compete with Walmart Inc., the top grocery seller in the U.S., as well as Amazon.com Inc. as it continues to expand into food sales.

As the largest and second-largest U.S. supermarket operators respectively, Kroger and Albertsons had anticipated that the merger would draw scrutiny from antitrust regulators, who have ramped up enforcement under the Biden administration.

The deal would create a powerhouse in the U.S. supermarket industry that would generate around $812 billion in combined annual revenue, according to an estimate by market research firm IBISWorld. Kroger and Albertsons hold a combined market share of 13% of U.S. grocery sales, ranking them just below Walmart at 22%.

Lawmakers have expressed concerns about the deal's potential effect on consumers. Executives from both companies appeared before a Senate subcommittee last week, where they vowed to keep prices low and protect workers' jobs should the deal move forward.

The companies, which operate stores in places including Southern California, Texas and Washington, D.C., have said they expect to sell overlapping stores to win regulatory approval.

J.P. Morgan analysts estimate that the two companies might have to sell off 7% to 10% of their footprint to appease regulators. About 57% of Albertsons stores are located within 5 miles of a Kroger location, BMO Capital Markets analyst Kelly Bania said in October.
